statement:
Consider a sequence $(a_n)=\{a_0,a_1,a_2,a_3,\ldots\}$ and given
$M\in {\mathbbmss{R}}$ consider any monotonically nonincreasing function
$f:[M,+\infty)\to {\mathbbmss{R}}$ which extends the sequence, i.e.
$$f(n) = a_n \qquad \forall n\ge M$$

An example is $$a_n = 2n\qquad \to\qquad f(x) = 2x$$ (the former being
the sequence $\{0,2,4,6,8,\ldots\}$ and the later the doubling function
for any real number.

We are interested on finding out when the summation
$$\sum_{n = 0}^{\infty}a_n$$ converges.

The integral test states the following.

The series $$\sum_{n = 0}^{\infty}a_n$$ converges if and only if the
integral $$\int_M^\infty f(x)\, dx$$ is finite.
